comments:
The latest stable build of Eclipse-gtk (20011219) crashes during startup on 
Linux Redhat 7.2. The redhat 7.2 is updated with the latest updates from Redhat 
using up2date. All that Eclipse displays before crashing is the logo. Eclipse 
does not write a log file before crashing. The following is the output from the 
command ">eclipse &>"

Warning: Couldn't load the 
pixmap /usr/local/eclipse/splash/en_US/splash_full.xpm.

Warning: Couldn't load the pixmap /usr/local/eclipse/splash/en/splash_full.xpm.

Exception launching the Eclipse Platform:
java.lang.NoClassDefFoundError: org/eclipse/swt/widgets/Widget
	at java.lang.Class.newInstance0(Native Method)
	at java.lang.Class.newInstance(Class.java:237)
	at 
org.eclipse.core.internal.plugins.PluginDescriptor.createExecutableExtension
(PluginDescriptor.java:87)
	at 
org.eclipse.core.internal.plugins.PluginDescriptor.createExecutableExtension
(PluginDescriptor.java:116)
	at 
org.eclipse.core.internal.plugins.ConfigurationElement.createExecutableExtension
(ConfigurationElement.java:96)
	at org.eclipse.core.internal.runtime.InternalPlatform.loaderGetRunnable
(InternalPlatform.java:483)
	at java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke(Native Method)
	at org.eclipse.core.internal.boot.InternalBootLoader.getRunnable
(InternalBootLoader.java:472)
	at org.eclipse.core.internal.boot.InternalBootLoader.run
(InternalBootLoader.java:817)
	at org.eclipse.core.boot.BootLoader.run(BootLoader.java:285)
	at java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke(Native Method)
	at org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main.basicRun(Main.java:151)
	at org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main.run(Main.java:502)
	at org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main.main(Main.java:362)
From the error message, it looks like it can't find class Widget. This seems 
unlikely unless the window system is wrong. Did you put "-ws gtk" on the 
launcher command line (see the release notes)?
The original reporter was having trouble accessing bugzilla and sent the 
message shown below to me. On the strength of this, I am closing this PR.

---------cut here--------------------------------

> You're right. The problem disappeared when I invoked Eclipse with "-ws gtk".
> Thank you.
>
> However, I think the solution is somewhat hidden. I remember seeing the
> switches in the readme before I installed. But they are listed under
> advanced topics. Besides, the zip file has "gtk" in its name. So it did not
> occur to me that I also would have to pass "gtk" as commandline argument.
>
